posts.title: How to deploy Ghost with Docker
posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"Two things I did for the production deployment of Ghost: 1. Use an environment directive to point the server to the correct URL, either in the `run` command, or as I did, in the docker-compose file. 2. Create a Docker volume for Ghost's content folder. Again, I did this in my docker-compose file. The volume will have persistent state whether or not the container is running because it lives in your filesystem, not in the container. Here's the docker-compose file I'm currently using: ``` version: '3' services: ghost: image: ghost:1-alpine ports: - "80:2368" volumes: - /opt/ghost/content:/var/lib/ghost/content restart: always environment: # see https://docs.ghost.org/docs/config#section-running-ghost-with-config-env-variables url: "https://jefflazerus.com" networks: default: external: name: mean_default ``` Luca Bravo"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
Two things I did for the production deployment of Ghost:

  1. Use an environment directive to point the server to the correct URL, either in the run command, or as I did, in the docker-compose file.
  2. Create a Docker volume for Ghost's content folder. Again, I did this in my docker-compose file. The volume will have persistent state whether or not the container is running because it lives in your filesystem, not in the container.

Here's the docker-compose file I'm currently using:

version: '3'
services:

  ghost:
    image: ghost:1-alpine
    ports:
      - "80:2368"
    volumes:
      - /opt/ghost/content:/var/lib/ghost/content
    restart: always
    environment:
      # see https://docs.ghost.org/docs/config#section-running-ghost-with-config-env-variables
      url: "https://jefflazerus.com"

networks:
  default:
    external:
      name: mean_default

Luca Bravo
posts.custom_excerpt: Get Ghost running in a Docker container

posts.html:
CompuGlobalHyperMegaNet (a Division of Flancrest Enterprises):

Imagine the possibilities!

People serving people serving the technology that serves people.

CompuGlobalHyperMegaNet, a Division of Flancrest Enterprises, headquartered in beautiful Arvada, Colorado, have been at the forefront of technology since 2001, originally designed as a micro-enterprise to bring skateboard culture to Antarctica in the post-internet era, we soon found our true passion in a diversity of new technology, including:

  • Run-on sentences,
  • Blogophere/Twitterverse paradigms and synergies,
  • Acronymification services,
  • Client/Server clients and Server/Client servers

Dmitri Popov

posts.title: Problems I had upgrading containers with docker-compose
posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","markups":[],"atoms":[],"cards":[["card-markdown",{"cardName":"card-markdown","markdown":"This blog is running in the official ghost:alpine container. In a previous post I described the docker-compose.yml file that I used to bring up the application. It's all running on a Digital Ocean Ubuntu 16.04 VM. So far, so good. If a container version is upgraded on the repo, I hypothesized that merely running `docker-compose restart` would pull the most recent release. And indeed that is the case. Except that the database migration that was included in the recent Ghost upgrade didn't work, and consequently, the service never came up. So just running `docker-compose restart` did not do everything, although it did get almost completely through the upgrade. Next I tried just running `docker-compose up` and the upgrade choked at the same place as the previous attempt. I did start panicking a little at that point, as my website was still not showing up. For reasons I do not completely understand, doing `docker-compose down` then bringing it back up fixed the migration. Probably because I was getting this specific error: https://docs.ghost.org/docs/troubleshooting#section-task-execute-is-not-a-function. Docker-compose down/up removes the old running stuff and builds everything back up from scratch, so maybe the instruction to upgrade ghost-cli came after the instruction to install ghost itself. And they do talk about the CLI upgrade here: https://dev.ghost.org/its-time-to-upgrade-your-cli/ It's interesting how you learn about these issues after the damage is done. Bigger question: how to avoid them in the first place? Is it simply doing a dry-run in a dev environment, then working out the "bugs" before launching? The blog admin section in Ghost is no longer asking me to upgrade it, so everything is current. And I am going to move on to other things. Vadim Sherbakov"}]],"sections":[[10,0]]}
posts.html:
This blog is running in the official ghost:alpine container. In a previous post I described the docker-compose.yml file that I used to bring up the application. It's all running on a Digital Ocean Ubuntu 16.04 VM. So far, so good.

If a container version is upgraded on the repo, I hypothesized that merely running docker-compose restart would pull the most recent release. And indeed that is the case. Except that the database migration that was included in the recent Ghost upgrade didn't work, and consequently, the service never came up. So just running docker-compose restart did not do everything, although it did get almost completely through the upgrade.

Next I tried just running docker-compose up and the upgrade choked at the same place as the previous attempt. I did start panicking a little at that point, as my website was still not showing up. For reasons I do not completely understand, doing docker-compose down then bringing it back up fixed the migration. Probably because I was getting this specific error: https://docs.ghost.org/docs/troubleshooting#section-task-execute-is-not-a-function. Docker-compose down/up removes the old running stuff and builds everything back up from scratch, so maybe the instruction to upgrade ghost-cli came after the instruction to install ghost itself. And they do talk about the CLI upgrade here: https://dev.ghost.org/its-time-to-upgrade-your-cli/

It's interesting how you learn about these issues after the damage is done. Bigger question: how to avoid them in the first place? Is it simply doing a dry-run in a dev environment, then working out the "bugs" before launching?

The blog admin section in Ghost is no longer asking me to upgrade it, so everything is current. And I am going to move on to other things.

Vadim Sherbakov
posts.plaintext:
If a container version is upgraded on the repo, I hypothesize the merely running
 docker-compose restart  will pull the most recent release.
